context.text: Examples of the various forms of linear precoding include optimal transmission [2]–[6], transmit beamforming [1], [2], [4]–[9], antenna subset selection [10], and precoded orthogonal space-time block codes (OSTBC) [11].
The capacity achieving precoding matrix (or equivalently the covariance matrix) can be found using convex optimization techniques [2], [4]–[6], [12]–[15].
It is known that obtaining the optimal beamforming vector is an NP-hard problem requiring a large amount of computation [2], [4].
When the number of users is \$K\$, the capacity of the optimal transmission decays as \$O(K^{-1/M_{t}})\$ as the number of users grows large [2].
On the other hand, the decay rate of the average achievable rate of transmit beamforming is greater than \$O(K^{-2-1/M_{t}})\$ [2].

While the capacity growth rate of the optimal transmission is \$O(\log M_{t})\$ for the large \$M_{t}\$ asymptote, the average achievable rates of both antenna subset selection and precoded OSTBC scale much more slowly with the number of antennas [2], [10], [11].
Indeed, obtaining the optimal beamforming vector that maximizes the minimum SNR is an NP-hard problem for an arbitrary number of users [2], [4].

The capacity achieving covariance can actually be chosen using semidefinite programming [2], [4]–[6], [12]–[15] with the computational complexity \$O((M_{t}^{6}+KM_{t}^{2})\sqrt{M_{t}}\log ({1\over \epsilon}))\$, where \$O(\sqrt{M_{t}}\log({1\over \epsilon}))\$ is the iteration count and \$O(M_{t}^{6}+KM_{t}^{2})\$ is the arithmetic complexity for each iteration, where \$\epsilon\$ denotes an accuracy of the solution [5], [6], [13]–[15].
Indeed, to obtain the optimal beamforming vector is an NP-hard problem for an arbitrary number of users [2], [4].

Note that while the optimal minimum SNR maximizing beamforming requires a high computational load to compute the optimal beamforming vector because the optimization is an NP-hard problem [2], [4], our algorithm requires at most \$O(KM_{t}\min(M_{t}, K))\$, where \$\min(M_{t},K)\$ is the maximum number of iterations and \$O(KM_{t})\$ is the worst-case complexity for finding the minimum projection to the current beamforming vector.

While these two algorithms were developed independently, they actually function in the same way if the algorithm in [9] is modified to adjust for transmit normalization.
In contrast to [9], we also solve for the optimal expression for the two-user case with our cost function and extend this result to obtain a transmit signal covariance design method.
In case of \$K=2\$, for the transmit power minimization of the multicasting beamformer under rate constraints, the optimal solution is given in [9].

The algorithm in [9] can be shown to function identically to this algorithm if a normalization is enforced.

Even though the beamforming vector solution in this section will be the same as Algorithm 1 in [9] up to transmit power scale factor, we describe our algorithm in detail because the logic that is used in this section will also be used in determining a near optimal multicasting covariance matrix.

context.text: The Han-Kobayashi strategy gives the largest known achievable rate region for the two-user interference channel, and has been shown to achieve the capacity region of the two-user interference channel to within one bit [3].

From an information theoretical perspective, the simple two-user single-input single-output interference channel has been studied extensively in the literature (see [3] and references therein); however, the full characterization of its capacity region remains open, except for the case of strong interference [4], and the case of sum capacity in a low interference regime [5]–[7].

Recently, Etkin, Tse and Wang [3] offered a key insight into the optimization of Han-Kobayashi strategy by showing that a simple scheme of setting the private message power at the opposite receiver to be at the background noise level achieves to within one bit of the capacity region of the interference channel.
In fact, even for the single-input single-output Gaussian interference channel, joint decoding is necessary to achieve to within one bit of the capacity region [3].

The intuition is based on the approximate characterization of the capacity region of the two-user interference channel due to [3], which shows that to achieve to within one bit of the capacity region, any interference above the noise level should be regarded as common information.
